questions.question: When I was talking to James, Susie ……………… our conversation.
questions.description: To break in on a conversation is to interrupt it.

questions.question: James has agreed to ………………… the condition of my ancestral home every now and then.
questions.description: To check up on something is to examine or investigate it.

questions.question: Susie has ………………… with an interesting suggestion.
questions.description: To come up with something is to contribute.

questions.question: If you don’t want to fall into the debt trap, you should ..................... the money you spend on food and entertainment.
questions.description: To cut down on expenses is to curtail them.

questions.question: I wish I hadn’t dropped ……………….. school at
questions.description: To drop out of school is to leave school.

questions.question: He doesn’t get ………………… his siblings.
questions.description: To get along with somebody is to have a good relationship with them.

questions.question: Do you think you can cheat on the exam and then get ………………… it?
questions.description: To get away with something is to escape blame.

questions.question: The politician tried hard to ……………….. his bad image.
questions.description: To get rid of something is to eliminate it.

questions.question: It took me quite some time to get ………………. that assignment.
questions.description: To get through with something is to finish it.

questions.question: When they became rich, they started looking ……………… their neighbors.
questions.description: To look down on somebody is to despise them.

questions.question: …………….. drunk drivers.
questions.description: To look out for somebody or something is to anticipate them.

questions.question: I will not ……………….. any more nonsense.
questions.description: To put up with something is to tolerate it.
